stem: The nurse is caring for a client at 39 weeks gestation who is in active labor. Which assessment findings require immediate intervention?

itemContext.sbar: Situation: Jane Doe is a 28-year-old (G1P0) at 39 weeks gestation, now in active labor. Background: She arrived at 07:00, reporting spontaneous rupture of membranes one hour prior. Assessment: At 07:30, her contractions are every 2-3 minutes, lasting 60-70 seconds. Vital signs: BP 120/80 mmHg, HR 88 bpm, RR 20, Temp 98.8째F (37.1째C). Fetal heart rate (FHR) baseline is 140 bpm with moderate variability. Late decelerations are noted. Recommendation: Immediate intervention is needed to address the late decelerations and potential fetal distress. Notify the physician.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Jane Doe is a 28-year-old (G1P0) at 39 weeks gestation, now in active labor.
Background: She arrived at 07:00, reporting spontaneous rupture of membranes one hour prior.
Assessment: At 07:30, her contractions are every 2-3 minutes, lasting 60-70 seconds. Fetal heart rate (FHR) baseline is 140 bpm with moderate variability. Late decelerations are noted.
Recommendation: Immediate intervention is needed to address the late decelerations and potential fetal distress. Notify the physician.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: No significant lab values available at this time.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: No medications administered at this time.

rationale.correct: Late decelerations indicate uteroplacental insufficiency, meaning the fetus is not receiving enough oxygen. Immediate interventions are required to improve fetal oxygenation, such as repositioning the mother to her left side, administering oxygen via face mask, increasing intravenous fluids, and notifying the healthcare provider. These actions aim to maximize blood flow and oxygen delivery to the fetus.
rationale.incorrect: A fetal heart rate of 140 bpm is within the normal range of 110-160 bpm, indicating fetal well-being. Moderate variability in the fetal heart rate is a reassuring sign of a healthy fetal nervous system. Contractions every 2-3 minutes, lasting 60-70 seconds, are expected findings in the active phase of labor.
clinicalPearls: Late decelerations are a sign of fetal distress and require immediate intervention to prevent fetal hypoxia.
Normal fetal heart rate is 110-160 bpm. Variability reflects the interplay between the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems.
Maternal positioning is crucial for optimizing uteroplacental perfusion. Left lateral position is generally preferred.
rationale.questionTrap: The question asks for findings requiring IMMEDIATE intervention. While other findings are important to monitor, late decelerations pose the most immediate threat to the fetus's well-being. Focusing on the urgency of the situation is key.
rationale.mnemonic: VEAL CHOP: Variable decelerations - Cord compression; Early decelerations - Head compression; Accelerations - Okay; Late decelerations - Placental insufficiency. Remember to act quickly when you see LATE decelerations.
